p: Experiment 1: I manipulated the presence of shade, fertilizer, lime, and interspecific competition with a common co-dominant tree, the post oak Quercus stellata. I predicted that shade would have a significant negative effect on their growth, fertilization and lime addition would cause an increase in growth, and interspecific competition would lead to a decline in growth. Plants growing in shade should invest more in aboveground biomass, nitrogen and non-structural carbohydrates than unshaded plants [ 78, 92, 96]. Plants growing in low-nutrient soils should invest in belowground biomass and increased storage of non-structural carbohydrates [ 75]. Plants enduring interspecific competition should invest more in non-structural carbohydrates to buffer against negative effects of competition than plants not suffering from competition [ 95]. If eastern redcedars prefer to grow in high pH conditions (i.e. with lime), they should invest more in nitrogen and non-structural carbohydrates [ 97â€“ 99].
